Did you know- Cannabis has the distinction of being the plant with the longest shared history with man? It has been so changed by horticulture that is has no close relatives? That this plant (aside from providing a nice buzz) is a source for rope, cloth, oils, nutrients, fuel, medicine, and about a million other uses? That its fibers are stronger and longer than any other natural fiber, making it a prime candidate for papers and fabrics? That it's oil burns hotter and cleaner than any other natural oil - that includes petroleum. That its medicinal properties are so numerous I won't even bother here. That the first flag was made of hemp, and that the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution were drafted on hemp paper? That the writers of said documents owned plantations that grew hemp?
 Why is Marijuana illegal? The prison industry. Over 70% of prison inmates are there for drug offenses, over 80% of those are marijuana related crimes. Does the prison make more from the inmate over a ten year sentence than the government would if they legalized and taxed it? Probably. Besides all the ridiculous propaganda published in the early years( You have to see 'The Burning Question' and 'Reefer Madness') that convinced americans that their teenaged daughters would go out, smoke some pot, get raped, then jump off a building. 
 Ok- why is hemp illegal? Easy... the cotton industry. During the years of WW2 (and before) hemp was used to a great extent in the military, especially by the navy. There was a time when every rope, every net, every piece of rigging was made from hemp. In fact, the government condoned the growing of hemp during the war years to the extent that it paid farmers twice it's worth for growing it. The saddest thing about it is that hemp is a much better fiber than cotton. When wet it contracts, making it even stronger. It is a very simple plant, happy to grow pretty much anywhere, not subject to the climate restrictions of cotton. It doesn't deplete the soil as cotton does either. It has a renewable harvest of at least three times a year. 
 It is truly a renewable resource. In this day when we are using up our resources at an astounding rate (how many acres of rainforest a day are we up to?) we seriously need to rethink our options. 
 So why is it illegal again? Well, just think of the repercussions if it were made legal... and of course used for all these purposes. The cotton industry would be left in the cold, seeing as how a t-shirt made from hemp would last years longer. It would destroy the paper industry, wood mills would shut down left and right, (hey, my grandkids might actually see a forest someday!) The oil industry would collapse. We wouldn't need to bomb other countries for their oil anymore!
 Of course this is about hemp, not marijuana, so I'll not give you a long discourse on the medical properties, but they are endless, and they are wonderful.
 Several states have made industrial hemp legal, including Hawaii, Colorado, and Wisonsin... but the problem is the severe restriction regarding both it's growth (12 foot electrified fences and regular patrol) and it's sale. And of course, there aren't many cars that run on hemp oil, there aren't many paper mills in the market for hemp fiber, there aren't even any domestic plants that make the fabric (last I knew)
 And so another problem is revealed in that we would have to revamp entire industries to make way for a better product........
 lets all cross our fingers for progress
